thread.title: General Election 2017: Meet your new North East MPs

author: Chris Knight
title: General Election 2017: Meet your new North East MPs

locations.name: laura pidcock - labour north west durham

organizations.name: labour - stockton north) stockton north labour
sunderland west) labour partys pink bus

text:
Get daily   
Prime Minister Theresa May may have managed to hang on to her place in Government, but Labour continues to dominate the North East. 
The region voted overwhelmingly in favour of leader Jeremy Corbyn in the General Election, restricting the Conservative Party to just four seats. 
The Tory gain in Middlesbrough South and East Cleveland was cancelled out by Labour’s Paul Williams coming out on top in Stockton South. 
With that in mind, many of our MPs will be familiar faces in their constituencies. 
But after Thursday’s General Election , here’s a look at the men and women who will be representing the North East in Parliament. Anne-Marie Trevelyan (Conservative - Berwick) Conservative MP for Berwick Anne-Marie Trevelyan 
The Conservatives managed to hold on to the seat they earned in 2015 after Lib Dem stalwart Sir Alan Beith stepped down. 
Earning 41.1% of the vote, Ms Trevelyan has developed a high profile and was a staunch Brexiteer. Helen Goodman (Labour - Bishop Auckland) Labour MP Helen Goodman (Photo: Mirrorpix) 
Labour held on to the seat fiercely targeted by the Tories by a narrow margin - triumphing by just 502 seats. 
Ms Goodman is known for her opposition to Corbyn, but managed to hold on despite a visit to the area from Boris Johnson in the week before the vote. Liz Twist (Labour - Blaydon) Liz Twist (Photo: @TarkId=34098) 
Former regional head of health for union UNISON, Ms Twist took over from previous MP David Anderson, who announced his decision to step down in April for personal and health reasons. 
The Conservatives regained second spot from UKIP, but despite their push Twist came out comfortably on top, winning 26,979 votes. Ronnie Campbell (Labour - Blyth Valley) Blyth MP Ronnie Campbell (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) 
Labour stalwart Mr Campbell once again came out on top in the constituency he has represented since June of 1987. 
There had been doubts over whether Mr Campbell would contest the seat as he had to undergo chemotherapy last year to treat stomach cancer. 
But cheers filled Blyth Sports Centre as the defiant former miner was announced victorious in his seventh election. Roberta Blackman-Woods (Labour - City of Durham) Roberta Blackman-Woods 
The former Shadow Housing Minister was one of many to resign in 2016 after losing confidence in party leader Corbyn. 
But Ms Blackman-Woods held on to the seat she has occupied since 2005, boosting her majority in the process. Jenny Chapman (Labour - Darlington) MP Jenny Chapman 
Darlington was another top Tory target that Labour managed to fend off, slightly increasing their majority to 3,280 votes in the process. 
Ms Chapman racked up 22,681 votes and secured 50.61% of the total vote. Kevan Jones (Labour - North Durham) Kevan Jones MP 
Mr Jones has held the seat since 2001 and was voted in with a comfortable majority of more than 13,000. 
Speaking directly after his victory was confirmed, he claimed May’s “gamble” on a fresh election had “failed”. Laura Pidcock (Labour - North West Durham) Laura Pidcock - Labour North West Durham (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) 
Newly-elected Ms Pidcock, 29, is from Cramlington and studied politics at Manchester Metropolitan University. 
She won 5,234 more votes than her predecessor Pat Glass, who stood down. Grahame Morris (Labour - Easington) Grahame Morris (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) 
Mr Morris was re-elected with a majority of 14,892 and took home 23,152 votes. 
Speaking after the result was declared, he said that the Labour Party was attracting younger voters in a way he had never seen. Ian Mearns (Labour - Gateshead) Ian Mearns (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) 
Mr Mearns, who has held the seat since 2010, has campaigned against cuts to council funding, which has hit services such as social care. 
He had an important role at Westminster as chair of the Commons Backbench Business Committee, which helps decide what gets debated in Parliament. Mike Hill (Labour - Hartlepool) Mike Hill, Labour MP for Hartlepool (Photo: Handout) 
The first-time candidate held the seat despite Conservative pressure after former MP Iain Wright stepped down. 
But Labour’s majority actually increased under Mr Hill, rising to 52.5% of the total vote. Guy Opperman (Conservative - Hexham) Guy Opperman 
Considered the safest Conservative constituency in the North East, the Tories held the seat with a majority of almost 10,000. 
Mr Opperman, a former barrister and amateur jockey, is a Tory moderate with a key government role as a whip. Bridget Phillipson (Labour - Houghton and Sunderland South) Wearside MP Bridget Phillipson 
Ms Phillipson held the seat she has occupied since 2010, despite a small dip in her majority. 
Some commentators felt the Tories could pinch the Wearside seats, but Phillipson finished a comfortable 12,324 votes ahead of her nearest rival. Stephen Hepburn (Labour - Jarrow) 28,020 Stephen Hepburn MP 
Mr Hepburn, who is a former Deputy Leader of South Tyneside Council, boosted his majority to a massive 17,263 in the seat he has held since 1997, 
Speaking after the constituency result was announced, he called for the Tories ‘austerity agenda’ to be dropped immediately. Andy Mcdonald (Labour - Middlesbrough) Andy McDonald MP (Photo: Daily Mirror) 
Typically regarded as one of Labour’s safest seats, Mr McDonald’s majority dipped slightly despite increasing his share of the vote by nearly 9%. 
The constituency has remained red ever since it formed in 1974. Simon Clarke (Conservative - Middlesbrough South and East Cleveland) Simon Clarke (Photo: Evening Gazette) 
The former Oxford student, who lists George Boateng as his favourite ever Boro player, became the first ever Tory MP for the constituency. 
Standing at 6ft 7, the man nicknamed ‘Stilts’ at school is now Britain’s second tallest MP. Chi Onwurah (Labour - Newcastle Central) Labour Candidate for Newcastle Central, Chi Onwurah (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) 
Ms Onwurah held her seat in the first result to be declared in the latest General Election, edging out rivals Sunderland. 
The Newcastle United supporter has represented her constituency since 2010. Nick Brown (Labour - Newcastle East) 28,127 Labour candidate for Newcastle East, Nick Brown wins (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) 
Jeremy Corbyn’s chief whip polled 28,127 votes on a turnout of 63.71%, an increase on the 19,378 votes he received in 2015. 
Mr Brown, who has represented Newcastle East since 1983, returned to the role under Corbyn in October 2016 - the third time he has held the post in frontline politics. Catherine McKinnell (Labour - Newcastle North) Labour candidate for Newcastle North, Catherine McKinnell wins (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) 
Ms McKinnell, who was one of several MPs who quit the shadow cabinet in opposition to Corbyn in 2016, held her seat and increased her majority. 
She received 26,729 votes, up on the 20,689 votes she polled at the 2015 General Election. Mary Glindon (Labour - North Tyneside) MP Mary Glindon 
Ms Glindon kept her North Tyneside seat with 33,456 votes, while her nearest competitor Conservative Henry Newman bagged 14,172. 
Speaking after the result was announced, she said Labour’s success in the constituency had come about from discussing the NHS and education rather than just Brexit. Anna Turley (Labour) Anna Turley (Photo: Evening Gazette) 
Ms Turley managed to hold on to the seat she won back in 2015, despite her majority narrowly dipping. 
She secured 23,623 votes and boosted her share of the vote to 55.5%. Rishi Sunak (Conservative - Richmond) 36,458 Rishi Sunak (Photo: Evening Gazette) 
Mr Sunak comfortably held on to the seat which covers areas including Great Ayton, Stokesley, Bedale, Northallerton and Catterick. Read More 
He increased his majority to 23,108 for the seat which was previously held by former Tory leader William Hague, Phil Wilson (Labour - Sedgefield) Former British Prime Minister Tony Blair (right) stands with Phil Wilson (Photo: PA) 
The man dubbed ‘Blair’s heir’ retained his place in Parliament despite a fierce challenge from the Conservatives. 
The County Durham born and bred politician gained 3,927 votes on his 2015 results. Emma Lewell-Buck (Labour - South Shields) South Shields MP Emma Lewell-Buck 
The Shadow Education Minister first won the seat in a 2013 by-election after former MP David Miliband chose to leave the House of Commons. 
Ms Lewell-Buck believes her third election win in four years proves there was more at stake in the latest election than Brexit. Alex Cunningham (Labour - Stockton North) Stockton North Labour man Alex Cunningham (Photo: Evening Gazette) 
The seat had been a target for the Tory campaign as they sought to capitalise on a strong Leave vote. 
But Mr Cunningham retained his seat with ease, increasing his majority and share of the vote to 56.9% of the vote. Paul Williams (Labour - Stockton South) Dr Paul Williams (Photo: Evening Gazette) 
The biggest election shock on Teesside saw the practising GP edge out Conservative James Wharton to turn the seat from blue to red. 
Mr Williams bagged 26,102 votes, edging out his rival out by 888 votes. Julie Elliott (Labour - Sunderland Central) Julie Elliot MP 
Ms Elliott dispatched of her Conservative challenger with relative ease, racking up 25,056 votes on a 62.1% turnout, up from 57% in 2015. 
Speaking after the result was announced, she said she had spoken to 600 people during her campaigning, and vowed to uphold the promises she had made to them. Alan Campbell (Labour - Tynemouth) MP Alan Campbell 
The former teacher, who first became an MP back in 1997 came out on top once again, this time ahead of Conservative Nick Varley in second place. 
Mr Campbell collected 32,395, earning a majority of 11,666. Ian Lavery (Labour - Wansbeck) Ian Lavery (Photo: Daily Mirror) 
Mr Lavery enjoyed a landslide victory with 24,338 votes - more than half of the total vast. 
The former mine worker was involved in a heated debate on TV with Conservative Boris Johnson in the days leading to the election. Sharon Hodgson (Labour - Washington and Sunderland West) Labour Partys Pink Bus makes a stopoff at the Monument. Pictured Washington MP Sharon Hodgson. 
The MP, who has sat in Parliament since 2005, comfortably retained her place ahead of the second-placed Tory rival. 
She got 24,639 votes on a turnout of 60.4% but, despite increasing the number of votes she received on 2015, her majority was decreased by a few hundred votes. Read More
